But though the centralised administration justified their confidence by its superior efficiency, though at the end of the first century much had been acoomplished both in the interest of the govemment and of the govemed, the task was immense, and it may be doubted whether the govemment os Diocletian had overtaken its immensity3 it is certain that the govemment of Domitian had not. There were still multitudes oi questions which were decided by the courts or by the senate almost without interserence from the prime, and within this extensive though diminishing arena it was still possible for politicians to win an intluence that was almost independent of the favour of the emperor. It was possible sor an individual to confer so many obligations that men shrank from voting against his opinion in the senate and against his clients in the courts: . though this did not protect him from the necessity of giving in his adhesion to each successive govemment, it made it worth the while of every successive govemment to defer to him on condition that he should give it his hearty support. It may be doubted whether any govemment which disposed of so much patronage as the early emperors was so unfettered by routine in selecting the objects of its favour: even Nero had not a court, Domitian had hardly favourites, and a share of this patronage was within the reach of any citizen who could make it worth the emperor's while to court him. Nor was this all: a Vibius Crispus ora Marcellus Eprius (Tac. de Oratoribus, vm. 3) could extend the influence to which he owed the friendship of Caesar by an ostentation of that friendship: men shrank from offend- ing the intimate of the Palace‚ is they did not shrink from disobliging a man who had obliged them, or their colleagues whom he had obliged. All this together made up the position which Tacitus and his contemporaries designate by the compre· hensive term potentat. And potentrb was not to be had i .
